text: well it was really a community that I
grew up in um you know uh in terms of my
the culture that was right around me
that is my the people who I would call
my friends and family for the most part
they were colored people
um and uh my mother and father had a big
effect on me my paternal grandfather my
maternal col grandmother had a big
effect on me there was a woman next door
called Miss Johnson who was actually
very large woman about maybe she weighed
about 400 PBS she had a huge effect on
me she was a great Storyteller and I
used to ask her to tell me stories all
the time and when kids were out playing
uh well we didn't have stickball in the
street but our version of softball or
baseball in the back alley um I would
most likely be found talking to Miss
Johnson asking her to tell me often some
of the same stories over and over again
and so I think that my desire to hear a
story which came from when I was very
young is still with me now and had a
huge influence on Me on the minister of
my church and his wife uh had a big
effect on me and then um I think the the
tougher part uh had to do with um my
schooling in junior high uh because the
kids in that school really stayed in
groups that had mostly to do with with
race and um and social class so for
example even among the Jewish kids it
was really clear to me that they had a
certain pecking order and the the um the
kids whose families had recently come
for example from Eastern Europe were um
segregated again away from those who
were more assimilated um and that really
B bothered me and you know when
something bothers you you can on the one
hand turn it into something which I've
tried to do in my life but there's
another way in which the fact of it the
fact of it never goes away and you sort
of see those same themes in your own
life and and certainly we live in a
world that may not be segregated in the
way that parts of this country were but
we live in a very tribal kind of world
now where there seems to be uh
a there seems to be a almost un
unsurmountable challenge in terms of how
do we soften those borders and
boundaries
